+package io.debezium.spi.converter;
+
+import java.sql.Types;
+import java.util.Optional;
+
+import io.debezium.common.annotation.Incubating;
+
+/**
+ * A definition of a converted relational column.
+ *
+ * @author Randall Hauch
+
+ */
+@Incubating
+public interface RelationalColumn extends ConvertedField {
+
+    /**
+     * Get the {@link Types JDBC type} for this column
+     *
+     * @return the type constant
+     */
+    int jdbcType();
+
+    /**
+     * Get the database native type for this column
+     *
+     * @return a type constant for the specific database
+     */
+    int nativeType();
+
+    /**
+     * Get the database-specific name of the column's data type.
+     *
+     * @return the name of the type
+     */
+    String typeName();
+
+    /**
+     * Get the database-specific complete expression defining the column's data type, including dimensions, length, precision,
+     * character sets, constraints, etc.
+     *
+     * @return the complete type expression
+     */
+    String typeExpression();
+
+    /**
+     * Get the maximum length of this column's values. For numeric columns, this represents the precision.
+     *
+     * @return the length of the column
+     */
+    int length();
+
+    /**
+     * Get the scale of the column.
+     *
+     * @return the scale if it applies to this type
+     */
+    Optional<Integer> scale();

+     * Get the scale of the column.
+     *
+     * @return the scale if it applies to this type
+     */
+    Optional<Integer> scale();
+
+    /**
+     * Determine whether this column is optional.
+     *
+     * @return {@code true} if it is optional, or {@code false} otherwise

+    /**
+     * Get the default value of the column
+     *
+     * @return the default value
+     */
+    Object defaultValue();

replies.bodyText:
This is a little bit tricky as there is three-state value

no default value
default value set to null
defalt value

The problem is that it is a little bit cunterintuitive to use Optional to express it.
We could use logic

null - no default value
Optional.empty() - NULL default value
Optional.of - default value

The problem is that the usual convention is that Optional methods does not return null. So that's why we opted for defaultValue/hasDefaultValue combo.
The most clean solution migt be to use <Optional<Optional<Object>> but that onle looks little bit ugly.

replies.bodyText:
@gunnarmorling Yes I was considering that but then I decided against it - the reason was that if you want to apply more complex rules then you'd need to do the rule evaluation in each method.
So I decided it might be more conveninet to do it in a single step.
